Introduction

Pyruvate kinase deficiency is an autosomal recessive enzymatic defect within the glycolytic pathway that primarily affects red blood cells (RBCs).  Without pyruvate kinase, erythrocytes cannot generate sufficient adenosine triphosphate (ATP), resulting in chronic hemolysis.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



The mature RBC is unique in that it lacks a nucleus and organelles, including mitochondria.  As a result, RBCs rely exclusively on anaerobic glycolysis to produce ATP and are particularly vulnerable to defects in glycolytic enzymes (

figure 1
).  The most commonly affected enzyme is pyruvate kinase, which catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, which generates ATP.



In pyruvate kinase deficiency, impaired ATP production disrupts ion transport, leading to water and potassium loss.  This disturbance affects membrane stability and contributes to the premature destruction of RBCs.  Affected RBCs are removed primarily by macrophages in the reticuloendothelial system, particularly the spleen (ie, extravascular hemolysis), which results in a chronic hemolytic anemia.



In addition, pyruvate kinase deficiency causes metabolic disturbances that lead to premature apoptosis of RBC precursors (ie, ineffective erythropoiesis).  This early loss of RBC precursors enhances intestinal iron absorption and leads to iron overload.



An interesting protective feature of pyruvate kinase deficiency is the accumulation of 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) (

figure 2
), an upstream precursor of pyruvate.  This leads to a rightward shift in the oxygen dissociation curve and more oxygen off-loading at the tissues (
figure 3
).  Therefore, patients with pyruvate kinase deficiency are relatively more tolerant of anemia at any given hemoglobin level.



Several isoforms of the pyruvate kinase enzyme exist.  Pyruvate kinase deficiency presenting with hemolytic anemia involves mutations in the gene that encodes the RBC-specific isoform (ie, PKLR gene).  PKLR gene mutations do not affect isoforms of pyruvate kinase in other cell types, which continue to function normally.



Pyruvate kinase deficiency requires 2 pathogenic alleles (eg, homozygous and compound heterozygous) for symptoms to manifest and is therefore inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.  It is the second-most common enzyme deficiency that affects RBCs; glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is the most common.

Clinical presentation



Although pyruvate kinase deficiency is a lifelong hematologic condition, the initial presentation can vary, depending on the severity of hemolysis.  This can range from fetal anemia with hydrops fetalis to mild anemia in adulthood.  Clinical findings are usually related to:



  • Anemia:  The severity can vary.  Because the anemia is chronic and patients have increased 2,3-BPG, some may have minimal symptoms (mild fatigue), whereas others require ongoing packed RBC (pRBC) transfusions.
  • Chronic hemolysis:  Jaundice may occur as early as the neonatal period, splenomegaly is due to hyperplasia of the splenic red pulp from increased RBC clearance by splenic macrophages, and bilirubin gallstones can lead to biliary colic and cholecystitis.
  • Transient aplastic crisis:  As with other conditions with chronic hemolysis, pyruvate kinase deficiency relies on steady production of new RBCs.  Acute illnesses (eg, parvovirus B19 infection) can suppress erythropoiesis, resulting in a rapid decline in hemoglobin and life-threatening anemia.
  • Growth impairment:  Growth impairment can occur in severe cases, likely due to a multifactorial etiology involving anemia, skeletal effects of ineffective erythropoiesis, and endocrine dysfunction from iron overload.

Differential diagnosis



  • Other inherited hemolytic anemias:  Like pyruvate kinase deficiency, these disorders present with clinical findings of hemolysis (eg, anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly).  RBC morphology can help distinguish these conditions, as follows:

    • Other RBC enzyme disorders (eg, G6PD deficiency):  Characterized by episodic, not chronic, hemolysis.  The complete blood count is normal between episodes of hemolysis.  In addition, blister cells are often visualized on peripheral smear (
      image 1
      ).
    • Hemoglobin disorders (eg, sickle cell disease, thalassemia):  Can be distinguished from by RBC morphology (eg, sickled RBCs (
      image 2
      ), target cells (
      image 3
      )).
    • RBC membrane disorders:  Includes spherocytosis (
      image 4
      ) and elliptocytosis (
      image 5
      ).
  • Immune-mediated hemolytic anemias (eg, alloimmune hemolytic disease of the newborn, autoimmune hemolytic anemia):  Can be distinguished from pyruvate kinase deficiency via a positive direct antibody (Coombs) test.
  • Other causes of neonatal jaundice (eg, benign neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, breastfeeding failure jaundice):  Pyruvate kinase deficiency can present at birth with indirect hyperbilirubinemia, so it can be difficult to distinguish it from other causes of neonatal jaundice.  Anemia and severe, prolonged neonatal jaundice (ie, >1 week) raise suspicion for an inherited hemolytic anemia.

Diagnosis



Pyruvate kinase deficiency should be suspected in those with unexplained chronic anemia or a family history.  Diagnostic evaluation involves:

Complete blood count and peripheral smear



  • Decreased hemoglobin concentration:  Due to chronic hemolysis.
  • Normal mean corpuscular volume.
  • Increased reticulocyte count:  Due to compensatory RBC production.
  • RBC morphology:  Generally normal but may show echinocytes (ie, burr cells), which are erythrocytes with short, evenly-spaced projections (
    image 6
    ).
  • Normal white blood cell and platelet morphology.

Hemolysis testing



  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase:  This increase is due to hemolysis.
  • Increased indirect bilirubin:  The rise is due to excess bilirubin production that overwhelms hepatic conjugation.
  • Low/normal haptoglobin:  With ineffective erythropoiesis, the premature death of RBC precursors releases free hemoglobin into plasma, lowering haptoglobin levels.  However, the predominant RBC destruction occurs in splenic macrophages (extravascular hemolysis), which does not release free hemoglobin and does not lower haptoglobin.
  • Negative direct antibody (Coombs) test:  Hemolysis is not immune mediated.

Confirmatory testing



  • Enzyme assay:  Decreased pyruvate kinase activity in RBCs is diagnostic.  This test should be performed several months after the last transfusion to avoid a false-normal result.
  • Genetic testing:  Genetic testing is usually performed through genomic sequencing to identify a pathogenic variant in the PKLR gene.

Management



  • Anemia:  Folic acid supplementation is recommended due to increased RBC turnover and erythropoiesis.  pRBC transfusions should be considered for symptomatic anemia.

    • Mitapivat:  Can activate pyruvate kinase enzymatic function and therefore reduce hemolysis.  However, this treatment requires a genetic variant with some residual enzyme function.
    • Splenectomy:  May be considered in individuals who require frequent pRBC transfusions.  However, risks are associated with splenic removal (eg, sepsis due to encapsulated organisms, venous thromboembolism).  Therefore, splenectomy is individualized and performed after age 5, when the pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenzae vaccination series has been completed to minimize the risk for sepsis.
  • Hyperbilirubinemia:  Phototherapy and/or exchange transfusion may be necessary during the neonatal period for severe hyperbilirubinemia.  Cholecystectomy may be considered in patients with symptoms related to gallstones.
  • Iron overload:  The overload is due to increased iron absorption related to ineffective erythropoiesis.  This is further enhanced with pRBC transfusions.  Patients require serial ferritin levels, and chelation therapy should be considered to prevent further complications (eg, cirrhosis, heart failure).

Prognosis



The prognosis depends on the degree of hemolysis.  Patients with adequate compensatory erythropoiesis typically have mild symptoms and a normal life expectancy.  Those with moderate to severe hemolytic anemia may have reduced quality of life related to complications (eg, gallstones, iron overload).

Summary



Pyruvate kinase deficiency is an autosomal recessive enzymatic defect within the glycolytic pathway that primarily affects red blood cells and results in chronic hemolysis.  Clinical manifestations include neonatal jaundice, anemia, splenomegaly, and gallstones.  Management is mainly supportive, with splenectomy and transfusions in severe cases.
